section.name: Introduction
section.p: Moria is implemented with a SOAP interface. The easiest way to use Moria is to use a SOAP implementation for the same programming language used by the service (that are going to use Moria). See the last section for more information about SOAP implementations for different programming languages.

Normally the SOAP implementation contains tools for generating stubs from the WSDL interface. The stubs works as the local representation of Moria and makes the communication between the web service and Moria totally transparent. How to use the stubs varies between SOAP implementations thus the SOAP implementation's documentation contains important documentation to understand how to use a web service as Moria.

section.name: WSDL Interface
section.p: The WSDL interface defines Moria's API and is best documented by the WSDL it self and the Javadoc for the classes used to implement Moria. A deployed Moria instance has it's own auto-generated WSDL, available via HTTP. For the URL to the WSDL file you should contact the administrators of the Moria installation you use.
The different versions of the Moria API are backwards compatible.

subsection.name: Version 1.0
subsection.p: Version 1.0 supports the regular Moria authentication and verification of user existence.
Javadoc for the implementation describes the available methods in detail.

subsection.name: Version 1.1
subsection.p:
Version 1.1 extends the 1.0 version and also support the following:
Proxy authentication
Utilities for user groups
Javadoc for the implementation describes the available methods in detail.
